moves.1... e5: The King's pawn defense.I am comfortable playing this position from any side.
moves.2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Nc3: Four knights opening.It is recognized as a drawing opening,but it still is good.
moves.3... Bb4: More normal is 3...Nf6,but this is not at all that bad.
moves.4. Nd5: This knight move bears a similar resemblance to Shrov-Kramnik variation of the English Opening.
moves.4... Bc5 5. c3: Aiming for 6.d4 with the clasical pawn center
moves.5... Nf6 6. d4 exd4 7. cxd4 Bxd4: ? better is 7...Bb6 with a slightly inferior game.
moves.8. Nxd4 Nxe4 9. Bf4: White has a material advantage of a bishop for 2 pawns.
moves.9... Nd6 10. Bxd6 cxd6: Now White has a good-sized advantage
moves.11. Bc4 O-O 12. O-O Qh4 13. Nxc6: The only way to get out of the pin.
moves.13... dxc6 14. Ne3 d5: White's minor pieces are forced back.
moves.15. Bd3 Be6 16. Qf3: Looking for a possible trade of Queens after 17.Qg3
Every trade makes the game closer to an endgame,which the 2 pawns could be worth the Bishop
moves.21... g6 22. Bh3: An odd retreat,looking for new life once the c6-pawn moves  on the h1-a8 diagonal or a possible redeployment to f1.
moves.23... b6: All according to plan.The h1-a8 diagonal looks more appetizing now.
moves.24. Qe4: The queen is very powerful now.
moves.24... Qd8 25. Re1 f5 26. Qe6+ Kf8 27. g3: The bishop is looking for g2.
moves.27... Qe8: ??The trade looks good now since the d-pawn might have its say,but...
moves.28. Qd6+: ! The Queen is lost.Black resigns.Comments are welocme.
